TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is a private entrepreneur who has registered as a payer of the single ( unified ) tax in accordance with LAW “ On LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE , with further amendments ( “ the Presidential Decree ” ) .

CARDINAL . DATE , when the applicant imported goods into GPE , he was requested by the customs authority to pay value - added tax ( “ NORP ” ) in accordance with the PERSON “ On Value - Added Tax ” of DATE ( “ the GPE ” ) .
CARDINAL . NORP The total amount of the LOC imposed by the customs authorities was CARDINAL NORP hryvnias ( ORG ) . The applicant paid the ORG required .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant instituted proceedings in ORG against the customs authority and a local department of ORG , seeking recovery of the VAT , arguing that he was covered by the simplified tax regime , as provided by LAW . He specified that according to section CARDINAL of the Law “ On State Support for Small Business ” ( “ the Small Business Act ” ) the simplified system of taxation provided for the replacement of taxes and duties by the single ( unified ) tax . He further claimed that according to paragraph CARDINAL of LAW the single ( unified ) taxpayer was exempt from paying ORG . Therefore , no VAT obligations could arise in the course of his business activity .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court rejected the applicant ’s claim as unfounded , stating that the principles established in LAW of LAW were not applicable as regards GPE because the relevant amendments had not been made to LAW as required by section CARDINAL of the latter Act . At the same time , the provisions of Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW indicated that the applicant ’s operations were subject to GPE . The court therefore concluded that LAW did not make any exemptions for private entrepreneurs covered by the simplified taxation regime . Moreover , having regard to paragraph CARDINAL of LAW , which laid down the criteria for registering under a simplified system of taxation , the court found that that system provided NORP exemption with respect to sales operations only and did not cover import operations .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , claiming that paragraph CARDINAL of LAW did not make any distinctions between import and sales operations . He argued that neither type of operation was subject to ORG if a person was registered under the simplified taxation regime .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of Appeal quashed the judgment of DATE and found for the applicant , noting that the NORP legislation provided for general and simplified systems of taxation . The latter provided for the substitution of ORG and other taxes and duties by a single ( unified ) tax . As the applicant had been registered under the simplified system of taxation , the first - instance court had wrongly referred to LAW in support of the conclusion that the applicant ’s import operations were subject to GPE . The court of appeal further noted that paragraph CARDINAL of LAW set out only the conditions for applying a simplified taxation regime and did not differentiate between business operations exempt from GPE . At the same time , paragraph CARDINAL of the Presidential Decree provided GPE exemption without any reservation as to the type of business operation .
CARDINAL . NORP The customs authority appealed on points of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Higher Commercial Court quashed the judgment of DATE and upheld the judgment of DATE . It referred to LAW , which provided that both sales and import operations were subject to GPE . The court further referred to paragraph CARDINAL of LAW which , in its opinion , had not merely set out criteria for the application of a special taxation regime , but had also indicated that the single ( unified ) tax was targeting income received from business operations . Accordingly , the court concluded that the NORP exemption established by LAW applied only to sales operations , while import operations fell under the general taxation regime . It further referred to the decision of ORG of DATE in which the same approach had been applied in a similar case .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG on points of law . He reiterated that paragraph CARDINAL of LAW made no distinction between business operations and provided for a general exemption of single ( unified ) tax payers from the NORP obligations . He further referred to the ORG decision of DATE in which the NORP exemption provided by LAW was interpreted as also covering import operations . He also claimed that under section CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL of the Law “ On the Procedure for Payment of Taxpayers’ Liabilities to ORG Purpose Funds ” of CARDINAL DATE ( “ LAW ” ) the courts were obliged to accept the interpretation of domestic law which was the more favourable to a taxpayer .
CARDINAL . On DATE a panel of ORG refused to open appeal proceedings in the applicant ’s case .
CARDINAL . According to paragraph CARDINAL of LAW , for DATE after the LAW came into effect the President of GPE was empowered to adopt decrees on economic issues not covered by the laws of the ORG .

CARDINAL . At the material time section CARDINAL of the Act provided , inter alia , that any physical person or legal entity importing goods with the purpose of using or consuming such goods on the customs territory of GPE should be considered to be a payer of GPE , except for those physical persons who were not registered as GPE payers and who imported goods within the non - taxable limits .
On DATE this provision was amended , providing , inter alia , that it applied to import operations regardless of which taxation regime had been chosen by the importer .
CARDINAL . According to sections DATE and CARDINAL of FAC was applicable to both sales and import operations .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Act provided that changes in the VAT charging regime could be introduced only by amendments to this Act .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW provides that the subjects of small businesses are , among others , physical persons who have registered as private entrepreneurs .

CARDINAL . According to LAW , the simplified system of taxation , accounting and reporting may be applied to the subjects of small businesses . The system provides for substitution of taxes and duties by a single ( unified ) tax .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL of the LAW provided that if the norm of the law or another normative legal act issued on the basis of the law , or if the norms of different laws or normative legal acts offered ambiguous or multiple interpretations of the rights and obligations of taxpayers and supervising authorities , the decision taken should be in favour of the taxpayer .

CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of the PERSON provides that a simplified system of taxation , accounting and reporting may be applied to , among others , a private entrepreneur who has employed during DATE a maximum of CARDINAL people under labour contracts and whose DATE income from the sale of products , works and services does not exceed UAH CARDINAL,CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of the PERSON provides as follows :
“ Small businesses paying the single ( unified ) tax shall not be considered payers of the following taxes and duties :
value - added tax , except for legal entities which have opted to pay single ( unified ) tax at the PERCENT rate ;
corporate income tax ;
personal income tax ;
land tax ;
duty for special use of natural resources ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted a decision in a dispute between a single ( unified ) tax payer and a customs authority concerning the charging of ORG on import operations . ORG noted that the NORP legislation provided for general and simplified systems of taxation which operated separately . The general system of taxation was regulated by the PERSON “ On the System of Taxation ” of CARDINAL DATE and by the laws dealing with particular taxes and duties . The simplified system of taxation was regulated by LAW and LAW . ORG further found that the plaintiff , having been registered under the simplified system of taxation , was not obliged to pay ORG on import operations because the plaintiff ’s NORP obligations had been replaced by the obligation to pay single ( unified ) tax . ORG therefore overturned the finding of the lower court suggesting that the NORP exemption was not applicable to import operations .

According to the information letter of CARDINAL DATE , ORG recommended the lower commercial courts to take that decision into account in the course of consideration of tax disputes . The decision was also published in the specialised legal journal on commercial jurisprudence .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted another decision in a dispute between a single ( unified ) tax payer and a customs authority concerning the charging of VAT on import operations . ORG noted that LAW provided for application of GPE to sales and import operations . At the same time , according to paragraph CARDINAL of LAW , the application of the simplified system of taxation depended on the amount of income earned from sales operations . ORG therefore concluded that the NORP exemption provided by LAW applied only to sales operations and not to import operations .

By the information letter of DATE , ORG , “ complementing [ its ] information letter of CARDINAL DATE ” , notified the lower commercial courts of that decision . The decision was further published in the specialised legal journal on commercial jurisprudence .
